items.title: Latest tokenize-rt prevents install on Python 3.4
items.body:
When on Python 3.4 upgrading this package, pip wants to install the latest "tokenize-rt" package, but it doesn't support Python 3.4 any longer.  Leading to a failed install.

When I downgraded tokenize-rt from 3.2 to 3.0.1 everything finally installed correctly.

Maybe tightening up your pinned versions in setup.py/cfg could help?

items.title: Library not working when included with AWS Layers
items.body:
Reproduction Steps

1> Create a Lambda Function(https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/getting-started-create-function.html)
2> Create a layer and associate it with your lambda created in Step 1(https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-layers.html). The purpose of layers is to have a shared library across multiple AWS Lambda functions. So here I am putting the future-fstrings library as a part of my zip file which is uploaded as AWS layer.

When I run the function I get the following error
`[ERROR] Runtime.UserCodeSyntaxError: Syntax error in module 'main': unknown encoding for '/var/task/main.py': future_fstrings
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "None" Line None
    None`

Assuming main.py contains my lambda function code
If I include the future_strings in same folder as my code then it works. 
AWS Lambda puts the shared libraries in /opt/ folder and I am dynamically adding opt directory to sys path `sys.path.insert(0, '/opt') ` Doing this way it throws error. 

 I do not know the internals how the library converts and when does the conversion code triggers but my hunch is I am doing something wrong here.

items.body: I am not sure why but I am unable to use this module because of the error- "SyntaxError: encoding problem: future_fstrings. I have python 2.7 on my machine.

items.title: Doesn't work after module docstring
items.body:
First of all, Great module! This saved me a ton of time in backporting from 3.6 to 3.5. One thing that would be great would be the ability to add the encoding cookie after things like a module docstring like so:

```
""" main.py
    Some module docstring text
"""
# -*- coding: future_fstrings -*-
```

I can also take a crack at it if not many other people are interested in this feature and are open to contributions.

items.title: How to use fstrings from py 2.7 shell?
items.body:
I am using python 2.7.x and have installed future-fstrings. It works when I run a py script using it. However, I don't find a way to use it from the shell. Can you tell the method to do so?

Also, instead of using:

    # -*- coding: future_fstrings -*-

Is there an associated `__future__` import?

items.title: Inclusion in setup.py?
items.body: I love how easy it is to convert code written using fstrings to pre 3.6 compatible string formatting, but I'd like to keep using fstrings and not have to have all users of my package install future-fstrings and I add the encoding to the top of the file.... So I'm wondering if there is a way to incorporate this into the build process of my setup.py such that it would run `future-fstrings-show code.py > code.py` on all the files if it were run on python <3.6.. any ideas?

items.title: Does not work in docstring position
items.body:
Normal f-strings work when put as docstrings.

However this codec rewrites them to expressions, which aren’t automatically assigned to `thing.__doc__` when in a docstring position (first item in a function/class).

To fully support f-strings, this package should transform e.g.

```py
def foo():
    f"""Hai
    {thar}
    """
    pass
```

to

```py
def foo():
    pass

foo.__doc__ = textwrap.dedent(
    """Hai
    {}
    """.format(thar)
)
```

(Or so, I didn’t check if `dedent` really does what we think it does)

items.title: CLI does not change input
items.body: When I run `future-fstrings-show` on a sample file like the one in the description with Python 3.7.1, the output is the unchanged content of the file. I would expect to see the replacements. Running code through the codec works fine on other python versions though.

items.title: python setup.py install doesn't work
items.body:
Great tool, love the ability to allow fstrings in python2.7!

I noticed a wierd corner case...

Broken example:
- Using a python 2.7.15 environment, build my custom "aperio" package, which uses future_fstrings (package_requires=['future-fstrings', etc])
- python setup.py sdist
- Change into a different python 2.7.15 environment and install my package
- tar -zxf mypackage.tar.gz
- cd mypackage
- python setup.py install
- launch python and import my package (in caching_setup.py I'm using your fstring hook)
```
>>> import aperio.common3.caching_lib.caching_setup
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/root/.local/share/virtualenvs/ex-caching-27-abxQ8rec/lib/python2.7/site-packages/aperioCommon-2.5.12-py2.7.egg/aperio/common3/caching_lib/caching_setup.py", line 14, in <module>
    from aperio.common3.caching_lib.cache_enabled_mixin import CacheEnabledMixin
  File "/root/.local/share/virtualenvs/ex-caching-27-abxQ8rec/lib/python2.7/site-packages/aperioCommon-2.5.12-py2.7.egg/aperio/common3/caching_lib/cache_enabled_mixin.py", line 1
SyntaxError: encoding problem: future_fstrings
>>> import future_fstrings
>>> future_fstrings
<module 'future_fstrings' from '/root/.local/share/virtualenvs/ex-caching-27-abxQ8rec/lib/python2.7/site-packages/**future_fstrings-0.4.4-py2.7.egg/future_fstrings.py**'>
```

Working example:
- instead of using python setup.py install, use pip to install my built aperio package
- cd mypackage
- pip install .
```
- launch python and import my package: no problem!
>>> import aperio.common3.caching_lib.caching_setup
>>> import future_fstrings
>>> future_fstrings
<module 'future_fstrings' from '/root/.local/share/virtualenvs/ex-caching-27-abxQ8rec/lib/python2.7/**site-packages/future_fstrings.pyc**'>
```

Not really a problem since I now know how to workaround the issue...but was confusing and maybe you can fix the setup.py install issue. Note the bolded text...the problem appears when future_fstrings comes from egg...

items.title: Python 3.4 & 3.5 SyntaxError: encoding problem: future_fstrings
items.body:
Hello there,

I am trying to use the module future-fstrings to automate builds for pip so that I don't have to change everything over to the much more verbose `string.format()` way.

However, every time that I try to use 

`# # -*- coding: future_fstrings -*-`

as the second line of my file I end up getting the following error before it even imports:
```
  File "setup.py", line 2
SyntaxError: encoding problem: future_fstrings
```
## Python Versions:

3.4 (32bit)
3.4 (64bit)
3.5 (32bit)
3.5 (64bit)

Please let me know if there is any additional information that you may need, and thanks in advance!

## Edit:

My repository and branch where I am testing out this module is the following:

https://github.com/TylerGubala/blenderpy/tree/fstrings-fix

items.title: Distrubution via Anaconda?
items.body:
Hey, I really like this package and would like to use it in a project that Im distributing via anaconda. Would it be possible for you to do a conda build so it can be included as a dependency? 

If you don't want to do the work, would it be OK if I build it and distribute it through my channel? I wouldn't change anything except to add the meta.yaml required by anaconda.

This package is great and I'm sure other conda users would appreciate being able to include it!

items.title: Implicit continuations with f-strings cause SyntaxErrors
items.body:
Line continuations that contain f-strings aren't properly transpiled.

Test script:
```python
# -*- coding: future_fstrings -*-
a = 1
b = 2

# Escaped newline
c = f"a={a} " \
    f"b={b}"
print(c)

# Implied line continuation inside parentheses
print(f"a={a} "
      f"b={b}")
```

Output with Python 3.6:
```
a=1 b=2
a=1 b=2
```

Error with Python 3.5:
```
  File "asd.py", line 6
    "b={}".format((b))
         ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```

items.title: Is future-fstrings compatible with Python 3.6?
items.body:
Hello,
I wanted to add support for Python < 3.6 for my package by using future-fstrings. However, when trying to run the program in Python 3.6, I get:

SyntaxError: unknown encoding: future_fstrings

Am I doing something wrong, or does future-fstrings only work on Python < 3.6?

items.title: SyntaxError with pylint
items.body:
test.py 
```python
# -*- coding: future_fstrings -*-
def test():
    d = {
    }
```


```console
$ pylint test.py
E:  2, 0: EOF in multi-line statement (syntax-error)
...
```

🤔

items.title: SyntaxError for strings with unicode chars
items.body:
```python
# -*- coding: future_fstrings -*-
def test(a):
    print f"ЙЙЙЙЙ {a}"
test(1)
```


```console
$ python2.7 test.py
ЙЙЙЙЙ 1
```

but


```python
# -*- coding: future_fstrings -*-
def test(a):
    print f"ЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙЙ {a}"
test(1)
```


```console
$ python2.7 test.py
  File "test.py", line 2
SyntaxError: ('EOF in multi-line statement', (3, 0))
```

🤔

items.title: Has issues with several characters: '!', ':', '{', '}' (maybe more)
items.body:
As pointed out [on reddit](https://www.reddit.com/r/Python/comments/6zhe3u/futurefstrings_a_backport_of_fstrings_to_python36/dmvcsa6/) there's a few bugs with some format-special characters.

These are mostly due to using `string.Formatter`, a better implementation would reimplement `string.Formatter` with more clever.
